title: Adam Levine on life after leaving 'The Voice': 'I'm just, like, a stay-at-home dad'
text:
CLOSE

Adam Levine shares that he's been spending most of his time being a stay-at-home dad. (Photo: Charles Sykes, Charles Sykes/Invision/AP)

It's been about four months since Adam Levine left "The Voice." What has the Maroon 5 frontman been up to since then? He works as a stay-at-home dad.

Levine stopped by "The Ellen DeGeneres Show" on Monday where he shared that he's been spending a lot more time with his new family.

"Just to be able to stop in this moment to spend time with my new young family and just have the greatest time ever," the father of two told Ellen. "Now I’m just, like, a stay-at-home dad. I just stay home and do very little. It’s great."

Levine shares two girls with his wife, Behati Prinsloo: Dusty, 3, and Gio, 1.

Ellen noted that her guest is a very "hands-on" father because he's always out with his kids.

The former coach on "The Voice" said he loves spending more time with his daughters, even though he does miss the show.

"I’m obsessed with them. I know that’s a good thing, because they’re my children … that’s why I don’t do much," he said. "I genuinely adore them in a way that I never knew I could adore any little person."

Last week, fellow "Voice" coach Blake Shelton said he missed his friend Levine.

"I’m having, like … What is it when the person gets separated from their kidnapper? I’m having Stockholm syndrome," Shelton said Tuesday during the fourth night of blind auditions.

But the country crooner doesn't have to miss Levine's disses and sabotaging too much, because Kelly Clarkson stepped in and kept the heat on.

"I have to fill this seat properly," Clarkson said, referring to Levine's old chair. "I feel like Adam’s going to definitely make fun of me if I don’t go in on Blake. I guess I’ll do it."

Levine's wife credited him with helping her get through postpartum depression.

Over the summer, Prinsloo joined model Kate Upton's #sharestrong social media campaign encouraging empowerment and positivity and shared a rare photo of her and her kids.

"Here’s to the sleepless nights, bleeding nipples, crying, laughing, the highest of highs and lowest of lows and everything in between," Prinsloo wrote on Instagram alongside a picture of herself holding her two daughters.
